Super cool to hear the breakdown on this. This is what my sister-in-law does, it’ll be good to know a little more of the science behind it the next time that we talk!

A PET scanner just measures radiation, it doesn't emit it. The radiation is emitted by the tracer injected into the patient. It is not a particle accelerator.

By constrast, a linear acceleration is used to accelerate electrons (or other particles) so fast that they give off radiation when they collide with patient at a certain depth.

It's saving lives. It pinpointed the melanoma on my arm. The second scan was so precise that the surgeon was able to remove it completely and I have full use my arm. Amazing technology and a great surgeon. This, within the past month.

How does a Proton decay into a Neutron and a Positron?  They have more mass than it does.

So, antimatter is emitted by matter, at least one isotope of matter, as a natural product of radioactive decay. So why are scientists in general, or even individually, not acknowledging this as a reason why they do not see antimatter stars, galaxies, etc.?

The half-life of a radioactive substance is dependent on the isotope used, not the compound that it's used in. Stating that "A common radio tracer used is FDG, and it's half-life is about 110 minutes" is very strange and potentially misleading if you don't also give the particular radioactive isotope used (fluorine-18)

In the past people have had particle accelerators in their homes without even knowing it. I'm refering to the picture tube of the old time tv sets. Nowadays we have flat screens but back in the old days we had these big old cr tubes and they worked by accelerating particles onto a phosphorescent screen.  In fact people were warned not to sit too close to the tv set lest they get radiation poisoning. Believe it or not!

I wondered how a proton can decay into a neutron and other particles, since a neutron weighs more than a proton.  It seems like some other particle (or some energy) would have to be introduced into the system to add enough mass-energy to the proton to get it up to neutron mass.  So I Googled.  I'm right that neutrons weigh more than protons.  But everyplace I look agrees that protons can decay to neutrons or neutrons can decay to protons -- it can go either way.  If the sources explain how that's possible, it's beyond my understanding.  It's something about lower energy state, but why would a proton in the nucleus of an atom go to a lower energy state (enough energy to make up the difference in mass to become a neutron AND create some other particles) just by being in the nucleus of a different element when the reaction is finished?  Nuclear physics makes me feel stupid.

I had this type of radioactive "dye" injected into me following a liver transplant.
I had to get a special type of scan which would highlight the molecules as they accumulated in my liver. The main purpose of the scan was to detect any leaks in my bile ducts following the surgery.

While the scan was going on I got to see the monitor, and you could make out the outline/shape of my liver through the myriad of dots that would appear on the display.

Aaaaand now I get to hopefully live long enough to see the cancer set in 😅🙌

So would a doctor, nuclear chemist, or a nuclear physicist make the radio tagged molecule for the scan.

I was talking to a classmate of mine who just graduated with a BS in chemistry and we were discussing what jobs a nuclear chemist would have and how they differ from a nuclear physicist. I'm not too sure myself but it seems to me that a nuclear physicist would produce the raw chemical (I assume that transmutation using a cyclotron doesn't have a 100% efficiency for transmutation) while a nuclear chemist might develop ways to separate the two or further purify it.

Like with heavy water you could theoretically purify it using electrolysis using the fact that the OD bond is 3% shorter than an OH bond meaning that when splitting H2O you would first split H2O before D2O. I guess mainly what type of job would best suit a nuclear chemist and what would best suit a nuclear physicist and where does the nuclear engineer fit in that spectrum.

The University of British Columbia has a full sized cyclotron (TRIUMF) for the same purpose, and has a very long pipe conduit routed to the teaching hospitals on campus.
Cardinal Healthcare has a cyclotron facility here in north Houston that is just a few miles from Bush Intercontinental Airport, and thy fly their FDG all over the country.

You also forgot about proton beam therapy which can precisely dump all of its energy at a specific depth and not irradiate tissue either in front of or behind the target. This is used for a number of different types of tumors,  including brain, breast, heart, neck, and prostate cancers.

So the question might arise: If the cyclotron is in the basement, what's on the floor above it? At Johns Hopkins, in the eighties, it was The Courtyard Cafe. People would lounge around eating lunch not knowing what was just beneath them. Was there radiation? I have no way of knowing (I doubt it); however, there was certainly electonic hash. This I know, because I used to string coax through the adjacent corridor.
